 “Give, and it shall be given to you. For whatever measure you deal out to others, it will be dealt to you in return.” 

“Charity shall cover the multitude of sins”
(i like bible quotes, :)   )

adapted from The Star Thrower
by Loren Eiseley (1907 - 1977)

Once upon a time, there was a wise man who used to go to the ocean to do his writing. He had a habit of walking on the beach before he began his work.

One day, as he was walking along the shore, he looked down the beach and saw a human figure moving like a dancer. He smiled to himself at the thought of someone who would dance to the day, and so, he walked faster to catch up.

As he got closer, he noticed that the figure was that of a young man, and that what he was doing was not dancing at all. The young man was reaching down to the shore, picking up small objects, and throwing them into the ocean.

He came closer still and called out "Good morning! May I ask what it is that you are doing?"

The young man paused, looked up, and replied "Throwing starfish into the ocean."

"I must ask, then, why are you throwing starfish into the ocean?" asked the somewhat startled wise man.

To this, the young man replied, "The sun is up and the tide is going out. If I don't throw them in, they'll die."

Upon hearing this, the wise man commented, "But, young man, do you not realize that there are miles and miles of beach and there are starfish all along every mile? You can't possibly make a difference!"

At this, the young man bent down, picked up yet another starfish, and threw it into the ocean. As it met the water, he said, "It made a difference for that one."

lenders.occupational_info:
U.S. Census Bureau
Technical Assistance and Capacity Building
International Assistance Area

In this position, I work on reimbursable projects in developing countries, which directly contributes to the Census Bureau's core mission, “sharing our expertise globally.” This is accomplished by providing technical assistance and training to build statistical capacity worldwide.  As a result of this effort many countries now have data to use for critical policy making decisions.

*Project Lead: Interagency Census Coordination
Project lead for the Interagency Census Coordination Committee meetings, which provides a forum for technical assistance agencies such as the United Nations Population Fund and the U.S. Agency for International Development. I am responsible for implementing future committee meetings, tentatively scheduled for 2008, which bring international donor organizations together for coordinating efforts in ensuring that developing countries have a successful round of 2010 censuses.

*Marketing Coordinator: International Assistance Area
Tasked with creating a series of informational literature to distribute among potential sponsors, host countries, and other technical assistance agencies to highlight the importance of taking censuses and using census data for policy making decisions.
 
*Geographic Information Systems Expert: Sudan Census Project
Assisting the Southern Sudanese government by providing Geographic Information System expertise to develop maps for use in the upcoming census of Sudan.  These are the first maps for this area of the country and are necessary to ensure an accurate count of the country’s population.

lenders.name: Suki
lenders.loan_because: To give opportunity is to give hope. Without hope we have nothing.
lenders.occupational_info: I am a pilot for a commercial airline in the United States flying passengers.

lenders.name: Yvonne
lenders.loan_because: My students are active participants in the loan process. It helps them become more aware of the world around them!
lenders.occupational_info: I am a 6th grade social studies teacher.

lenders.name: Troy
lenders.loan_because:
I greatly admire Kiva.org - I think it's one of the most powerful tools that have come from the information age.  Fully utilizing the extensive reach of the internet, Kiva.org has the ability to monetarily connect anyone in the world to a small business in an impoverished country.  

While a $800 loan to a small business may seem inadequate here in America, to a small business in a destitute country, it could be the difference as to whether they can afford medicine or food for their family.  It could be all the difference to their employee's and their family.  It could also be all the difference to their community.  

The greater and long term impact of helping a small business grow reaches far beyond the the business itself.
lenders.occupational_info:
I am a co-founder of an internet marketing company called CPAlead.com.  We provide unique and innovative online marketing tools to small and big website owners from all over the world.  

These ad display tools generate our clients revenues much greater than traditional online marketing networks.  We have helped over 150,000 people monetize their website's and as a result we were recently ranked the #1 fastest growing online marketing start-up by INC 500 magazine.  

To learn more about CPAlead, please visit http://www.youtube.com/cpalead

No corruption,  high moral by those applying for loans og motivated people who really does big affords and approaches to succeed with their work. To support small businesses means much to the local societies. Actually, I belive that micro loans are more powerful for fighting against poverty than most of the money given for "developping" poor people and countries by industrialized countries. But Fairtrade is even more important!
lenders.occupational_info: I'm a civil servant working with business steering by strategy, controlling, qualityprooving and economics in a big organisation.
